questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with left flank pain. On examination, she was febrile, had livedo reticularis and a blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg. She also has a history of a butterfly rash in the past.
Investigations revealed:
Hb 13.9 g/dL
WBC 6.5 x 10^9/L
Platelet count 110 x 10^9/L
Serum Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Urine dipstick analysis: blood ++, protein -
Which one of the following tests is likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anti-cardiolipin antibody, which is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS), a known complication of SLE that can cause thrombotic events such as renal vein thrombosis.
  • This patient has a history suggestive of SLE (butterfly rash), along with acute onset left flank pain, uncontrolled hypertension, hematuria without proteinuria, and livedo reticularis, all of which point toward renal vein thrombosis.
  • These features are classical for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, and anti-cardiolipin antibody is one of the key diagnostic markers of APLS.
  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is a disorder characterised by recurrent venous or arterial thrombosis and/or fetal losses associated with typical laboratory abnormalities.
  • These include persistently elevated levels of antibodies directed against membrane anionic phospholipids (ie, anticardiolipin [aCL] antibody, antiphosphatidylserine).
  • Other features are nonthrombotic neurologic symptoms, such as migraine headaches, chorea, seizures, transverse myelitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, thrombocytopenia or hemolytic anaemia, Livedo reticularis, Avascular necrosis of bone and Pulmonary hypertension.
  • Aspirin or warfarin is recommended for patients with thrombotic syndromes.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-Ro antibody (Option A) is seen in SLE and Sjögren's syndrome, especially associated with neonatal lupus and congenital heart block, but not specific for thrombotic events like renal vein thrombosis.

Anti-GBM antibody (Option B): Associated with Goodpasture's syndrome, which presents with hematuria and pulmonary haemorrhage, not with thrombosis or livedo reticularis.

ASOT (Option D): Antistreptolysin O titre is used to identify recent streptococcal infection; not related to autoimmune vasculopathy or thrombotic phenomena.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with breathlessness. She has a 2-year history of Raynaud's phenomenon. On examination, she had telangiectasia and tight skin around the mouth. She had no other systemic manifestations. Her investigations show an ESR of 70 mm/hr and positive anti-centromere antibodies. Which of the following is a typical late complication of this disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture is consistent with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), characterised by skin tightening limited to the face and distal extremities, Raynaud's phenomenon, and the presence of anti-centromere antibodies.
  • One of the characteristic late complications of lcSSc is pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), which develops slowly and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in this subtype.

Clinical Distinction Between Limited and Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis:

Explanation of other options:

Lung malignancy (Option B): Not a typical direct complication of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Myositis (Option D): More common in overlap syndromes or diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis; not typical in the limited cutaneous variant.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman has Raynaud's phenomenon. She also has difficulty swallowing and dyspnoea. Echocardiography shows right heart strain. Her BP was 150/100, and her renal function was deranged. Which one of the following antibodies is specific to this lady's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with Raynaud's phenomenon, oesophageal dysmotility, dyspnoea, right heart strain (suggesting pulmonary hypertension), and deranged renal function. These features are classical for diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
  • The antibody most specific for diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis is Anti-Scl-70 (Topoisomerase I), which is associated with interstitial lung disease (ILD) and renal crisis.

Antibody Association in Systemic Sclerosis

Explanation of other options:

Anticentromere antibody (Option A): Typically associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome) and late-onset pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). It is not specific to this patient's presentation involving diffuse organ involvement and renal dysfunction.

Anti-U1 RNP (Option B): Seen in Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD). It may present with features overlapping SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. It is not specific for systemic sclerosis alone.

Anti-RNA polymerase III (Option C): Also seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and particularly associated with renal crisis, but less strongly than Scl-70 when pulmonary findings dominate.

questions.text: Which antibody does not have Scleroderma as its phenotype?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anti-Ribosomal antibodies are not typically associated with Scleroderma as their phenotype.

  • Anti-Pm-Scl antibodies: These are often found in patients with overlap syndromes involving features of both Scleroderma and Polymyositis. (Option A)
  • Anti-Ku antibodies: These are associated with some cases of Scleroderma, particularly the limited cutaneous form. (Option B)
  • Anti-U1 RNP antibodies: These are more commonly associated with Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), which can have overlapping features of Scleroderma among other autoimmune conditions. (Option C)
  • Anti-Ribosomal antibodies: These antibodies are primarily associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are not a typical feature of Scleroderma.

choices.text: Renal transplant, as with creatinine damage, the damage is irreversible

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of systemic sclerosis is referred to the hospital with a complaint of headaches, blurred vision. On examination, her blood pressure is 230/120 mmHg, and there is bilateral papilloedema. Her creatinine is 5.2. Her ECG is suggestive of hyperkalemia.
Which of the following should not be prescribed for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a classic case of scleroderma renal crisis (SRC), marked by the sudden onset of severe hypertension, renal dysfunction, and hyperkalemia.
  • Assuming irreversible renal failure and opting for a renal transplant at this stage is incorrect.
  • While the creatinine is elevated, renal recovery is often possible, and renal transplant is rarely required.
  • ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) remain the treatment of choice even when creatinine is high. (Option B)
  • IV insulin is used to manage hyperkalemia acutely, and dialysis is indicated if hyperkalemia or uremia is refractory. (Option A and C)
  • Risk factors for SRC:
    1. Male sex
    2. African-american race
    3. Rapidly progressive skin involvement
    4. Use of glucocorticoids.
    5. UIII RNP antibodies
  • Pericardial effusion, tendon friction rub and new unexplained anaemia and thrombocytopenia are harbingers of a renal crisis.
  • BP should be reduced by 20/10mmHg each day using ACEI. ARBs are used only if ACEI is contraindicated.
  • Once ACEI is at its maximum dose, other antihypertensives may be added. ACEI improves the renal recovery and should be continued during dialysis, too.
  • Since there is intrarenal complement activation, Eculizumab may also be used.
  • TTP is a close DD, and ADAMTS 13 levels should be measured, as it will be normal in renal crisis.
  • Normotensive renal crisis has a worse outcome than hypertension.

questions.text: Which is not included in the pathologic triad for Systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Three cardinal pathomechanistic processes underlie the protean clinical manifestations and pathologic changes of Systemic sclerosis:
    1. Diffuse microangiopathy (Option D)
    2. Inflammation and autoimmunity (Option A)
    3. Visceral and vascular fibrosis affecting multiple organs. (Option B)
  • In general, autoimmunity and reversible vascular reactivity are early features of systemic sclerosis, whereas fibrosis and atrophy occur later in the disease.
  • Diffuse Microangiopathy is the first and primary pathogenic event and is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms, including telangiectasis, Raynaud's Phenomenon, digital ulcers, renal crisis, myocardial involvement and PAH.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presents to the clinic with a one-year history of intermittently painful fingers. The pain occurs commonly in low ambient temperatures, and there is commensurate skin colour change from white to blue to red. Each episode lasts approximately 15 - 20 minutes. She tells you that her mother suffered from rheumatoid arthritis and Raynaud's. Which bedside test could you perform that may indicate an underlying connective tissue disorder as the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presentation is typical of Raynaud's phenomenon. After recognising this, we need to differentiate between primary and secondary Raynaud's phenomenon.
  • Nailfold capillaroscopy is an important tool to differentiate primary Raynaud's from secondary.
  • Nailfold capillaroscopy is performed by applying a drop of oil onto the periungual region of the nail and using an ophthalmoscope set to 40 diopters to examine.
  • Abnormal findings such as dilated capillary loops, dropout, or haemorrhages suggest secondary Raynaud's.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon: episodic vasoconstriction affecting the tips of fingers and toes, and sometimes of the tip of the nose and earlobes.
  • Other features: Pallor (vasoconstriction), cyanosis (ischemia) and hyperemia (reperfusion).

Explanation of other options:

Capnography (Option A): Capnography is used to assess ventilation status, primarily in respiratory or anaesthetic monitoring. It has no role in Raynaud's diagnosis.

Cold water challenge (Option B): While it may provoke a Raynaud's episode, it does not distinguish between primary and secondary causes.

Digital artery closing temperature (Option C): It measures vasoconstrictive threshold but does not provide anatomical or pathological insights into capillary architecture or autoimmune involvement.

choices.text: Raynaud's phenomenon is the most common extracutaneous complication
Raynaud's phenomenon can precede systemic sclerosis by years
Renal and lung damage occur late in the course of systemic sclerosis
Pigment loss in systemic sclerosis may lead to a salt-and-pepper appearance

questions.text: Which is the wrong statement regarding Systemic Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Renal and lung involvement, particularly scleroderma renal crisis (SRC) and interstitial lung disease (ILD), typically occur early in the course of systemic sclerosis, especially in the diffuse cutaneous subtype (dcSSc).
  • These internal organ complications may be silent at first but can progress rapidly, especially within the first 4 years.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is indeed the most common extracutaneous manifestation. It may precede other signs of systemic sclerosis by several years. It presents as episodic vasoconstriction in fingers and toes and often affects the tip of the nose and earlobes. Nailfold capillaroscopy is useful in identifying early disease. (Options A and B)
  • The characteristic "salt and pepper" appearance of the skin results from pigmentary changes (depigmentation interspersed with areas of retained pigmentation), especially over the face and trunk. (Option D)

choices.text: Calcinosis cutis is more commonly seen with long-standing SSc, with anti-SCl-70 positivity
The calcium and phosphate levels are normal
Crystals are composed of calcium hydroxypetite
Paraspinal sheet calcifications may occur with neurological complications

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Systemic Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Calcinosis cutis is more commonly seen in long-standing limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, especially in patients with anti-centromere antibodies, not with anti-Scl-70.
  • The calcium and phosphate levels in these patients are typically normal, and the deposits consist of calcium hydroxyapatite crystals. (Options B and C)
  • These deposits often appear in the fingers, palms, and extensor aspects of the forearm. Large calcifications may cause local nerve compression or ulcerate the overlying skin.
  • Paraspinal sheet calcification can occur and may be associated with neurological complications. (Option D)

choices.text: This patient is likely to have anti-centromere antibody
The severity of the disease mentioned above can be assessed by the number of cutaneous telangiectasias
The disease involves the major pulmonary arteries
In patients suspected to have the above disease, a cardiac catheterisation should be done to confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with a history of GERD, digital ulcers and skin thickening for the past 10 years, now complains of exertional dyspnoea and bilateral pedal oedema. On examination, he has elevated JVP, a prominent pulmonic component of the second heart sound and PSM at the lower right sternal border. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The question deals with pulmonary artery hypertension in a patient with a history of Systemic sclerosis.
  • The long duration of the skin thickening, along with the development of symptoms, is suggestive of Pulmonary Artery Hypertension, most likely due to limited cutaneous disease.
  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is associated with anticentromere antibodies. (Option A)
  • The severity of PAH can be correlated with the number of telangiectasias. (Option B)
  • PAH in patients with lc SSc is due to obliterative arthropathy of the small pulmonary arteries.
  • PAH can be asymptomatic in patients, and hence in patients with suspected the diagnosis should be confirmed by a cardiac catheterisation. (Option D)
  • Endothelin 1 receptor antagonists Bosentan, PDE5 inhibitors Sildenafil, Guanylyl cyclase stimulator Riociguat and selective intra-pulmonary prostacyclin agonists, Selexipag, are used in the treatment of PAH.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady has tightening of the skin around her hands and mouth. She has several telangiectasias on her hands and complains of severely cold hands in winter. She was noticed to be pale.
Investigations show :
Hb 4.5 g/dl
MCV 105 fl
WCC 6 x 10^9/L
platelets 230 x 10^9/L
Iron 22 (14-29) μmol/l
Ferritin 155 (15-200)μmol/l
total iron binding capacity 50 (45-72) umol/l
Folate 11 (3-20) ng/l
Vitamin B12 - 85 (120-700 pmol/l)
What is the likely cause of anaemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has macrocytic anaemia (MCV 105 fL) and low vitamin B12 levels, while folate and iron studies are normal.
  • She also shows signs of systemic sclerosis, which can cause small bowel dysmotility and bacterial overgrowth.
  • Systemic sclerosis (SSc) often affects the gastrointestinal tract. In particular, small intestinal involvement impairs peristalsis, leading to stasis and bacterial overgrowth.
  • These bacteria utilise and degrade vitamin B12, resulting in B12 deficiency, despite adequate intake. This is the most likely explanation for her macrocytic anaemia.

Explanation of other options:

Pernicious anaemia (Option A): Pernicious anaemia is an autoimmune and associated with intrinsic factor deficiency. There's no clinical or lab evidence (e.g., gastritis, anti-parietal cell antibodies) supporting it here.

Secondary folate deficiency (Option B): Folate level is normal in this case (11 ng/mL), ruling this out.

Celiac disease (Option C): Celiac disease can cause malabsorption and anaemia, but is typically associated with iron deficiency anaemia and not isolated B12 deficiency. No history of diarrhoea or other features is provided

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of systemic sclerosis, complaints of fatigue and exertional dyspnoea of 3 months duration. He has also noted malena. On examination, he was pale with spooning of nails. What will be the likely finding on upper GI endoscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cause of chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc) is gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE).
  • This condition leads to mucosal vascular dilatation and chronic occult bleeding, often resulting in iron deficiency anaemia.
  • On endoscopy, the characteristic appearance is that of longitudinal stripes of ectatic blood vessels in the antrum, radiating outward from the pylorus, resembling the stripes on a watermelon, hence the term "watermelon stomach."

Explanation of other options:

Peptic ulceration (Option A): Although peptic ulcers can cause GI bleeding, they are not specifically associated with systemic sclerosis.

Oesophageal varices (Option B): Varices occur due to portal hypertension, which is not typically a complication of systemic sclerosis unless there's secondary liver involvement.

Gastric malignancy (Option D): This is an important cause of GI bleeding but has no direct association with systemic sclerosis or the typical presentation of GAVE.

choices.text: Localised scleroderma is more common in children
It spares fingers, and Raynaud's phenomenon is rare
Linear scleroderma can cross joints, leading to contractures and can cause growth retardation of long bones

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Localised scleroderma is more common in children (Option A).
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is rare, and it spares fingers. (Option B)
  • Internal organ involvement is rare.
  • Other forms include linear scleroderma, which may cross joints and lead to contractures and growth retardation in children.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon and autoantibodies, commonly seen in systemic sclerosis, are usually absent in localised variants.
  • Eosinophilic fasciitis is a disorder of adults that presents as skin thickening, having the same features as above. There will not be autoantibodies in SSc. Fingers will be spared, and there will be no internal organ involvement. It is often seen in association with myelodysplastic syndrome or multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man has a 6-month history of dry eyes and mouth. On examination, there was evidence of keratoconjunctivitis, parotid gland enlargement, and a Schirmer's test was positive. His blood tests reveal a positive ANA, Ro and La; extra nuclear antigens are also positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with the classical triad of xerostomia (dry mouth), keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes), and lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands, hallmark features of Sjögren's syndrome, an autoimmune exocrinopathy.
  • The presence of anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies further confirms the diagnosis.
  • The Schirmer test, which detects decreased tear production (<5 mm in 5 min), supports keratoconjunctivitis sicca and is a part of the diagnostic criteria.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option A): While SLE may present with ANA and constitutional symptoms, sicca symptoms with parotid enlargement and anti-Ro/La positivity are more specific to Sjögren's syndrome.

Rheumatoid Arthritis (Option B): RA can co-occur with Sjögren's but does not typically cause prominent dry eyes/mouth or a positive Schirmer test in isolation.

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener's) (Option D): GPA presents with upper and lower respiratory tract involvement and renal disease, not with sicca symptoms.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman has generalised joint pains and muscle aches. She also complains of gritty sensations in her eyes in the mornings. Blood tests show Anti-Nuclear Antibody ++, Rheumatoid Factor ++.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient most likely has Primary Sjögren's Syndrome, a chronic autoimmune disease characterised by lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands, most commonly the lacrimal and salivary glands, resulting in dry eyes and dry mouth (sicca symptoms).
  • Commonly affects middle-aged women.
  • The presence of glandular symptoms (e.g. gritty eye sensation due to keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and positive ANA and RF support the diagnosis.
  • Joint pains are also common in primary Sjögren's, often mimicking features of RA.
  • GI involvement can lead to atrophic gastritis.
  • Genital involvement can cause dyspareunia.
  • Extra glandular involvement is also seen in 1/3rd patients.
  • Peri-epithelial involvement is characterised by the accumulation of activated lymphocytes and hence is called autoimmune epithelitis.
  • Sjögren's Syndrome predisposes to the development of Maltoma.

Explanation of other options:

Polymyositis (Option A): Polymyositis presents with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes, not with dry eyes or ANA/RF positivity alone.

Reiter's syndrome (Reactive arthritis) (Option B): This post-infectious arthritis involves urethritis, conjunctivitis, and asymmetric arthritis. It does not cause dry eyes or parotid involvement.

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option D): PAN is a necrotising vasculitis affecting medium-sized vessels and presents with systemic features like abdominal pain, mononeuritis multiplex, and hypertension, not sicca symptoms or positive ANA/RF.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not present with bilateral parotid gland enlargement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amyloidosis typically presents with xerostomia (dry mouth) due to amyloid deposition in salivary glands, but it does not cause parotid gland enlargement.
  • In contrast, sarcoidosis, IgG4-related disease, and hyperlipoproteinemias (especially type I and type IV) are all known to cause bilateral parotid gland enlargement.

Conditions Associated with Bilateral Parotid Enlargement

choices.text: Death of a normal fetus at the 12th week of gestation
Premature birth at 35th week of gestation

questions.text: Which of the following does not fit the criteria for APLA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The revised Sapporo criteria for diagnosing APLA syndrome include the presence of vascular thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity along with persistent antiphospholipid antibodies. (Option A)
  • Pregnancy morbidity is defined by:
    1. One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus beyond the 10th week of gestation (Option B)
    2. One or more premature births of a morphologically normal neonate before the 34th week due to eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    3. Three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before the 10th week of gestation (Option D)
  • Laboratory criteria include
    1. Lupus Anticoagulant (LA),
    2. Anticardiolipin (aCL), and/or
    3. Anti-β2 GPI antibodies, at intermediate or high titres on two occasions, 12 weeks apart.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with left flank pain. On examination, she was febrile, had livedo reticularis and a blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg. She has also had a history of a butterfly rash in the past.
Investigations revealed:
Hb 13.9 g/dL
WBC 6.5 x 10^9/L
Platelet count 110 x 10^9/L
Serum Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Urine dipstick analysis: blood ++, protein -
Which one of the following tests is likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The likely diagnosis is lupus with secondary antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS), which is associated with positive anti-cardiolipin antibodies.
  • The patient is a middle-aged female with a history of butterfly rash, suggesting systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
    Now, she presents with:
    • Livedo reticularis
    • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count 110 × 109/L)
    • Hematuria with no proteinuria
    • Hypertension
  • These findings suggest renal infarction due to thrombosis, rather than glomerulonephritis mostly seen in lupus with secondary antiphospholipid syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-Ro antibody (Option A): Seen in SLE and Sjögren's but not associated with thrombosis or livedo reticularis.

Anti-GBM antibody (Option B): Associated with Goodpasture's syndrome, which causes rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with both hematuria and proteinuria, not isolated hematuria.

ASOT (Option D): Suggests recent streptococcal infection; not relevant here.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman has a deep vein thrombosis. Her previous history included investigations for miscarriages. Investigations revealed: Haemoglobin 11.9 g/dl, White cell count 4 x 10^9/L, Platelet count 30 x 10^9/L.
Which of these are likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient likely has Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), an autoimmune prothrombotic condition associated with both arterial and venous thromboses, as well as pregnancy-related morbidity such as recurrent miscarriages.
  • Key features include:
    • Venous thrombosis (e.g., DVT, pulmonary embolism)
    • Arterial thrombosis (e.g., stroke, MI)
    • Pregnancy losses, especially unexplained fetal death or recurrent early miscarriage
    • Thrombocytopenia (seen in ~40% of patients)
    • Livedo reticularis, leg ulcers, and neuropsychiatric symptoms
  • Detection of Antiphospholipid antibodies like lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, or anti-β2 glycoprotein I antibody confirms the diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Homocysteine level (Option A): Elevated homocysteine may predispose to thrombosis, but it is not typically associated with pregnancy losses or thrombocytopenia.

ANCA (Option B): Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are associated with small-vessel vasculitis (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis), not APS.

Protein C deficiency (Option C): Though a cause of thrombophilia, it is not associated with low platelets or pregnancy losses.
